info.description:
The time tracking REST APIs enable you to access time tracking information. These APIs provide the ability to: 
* Enable workers to check in and check out of work and to review and modify their recent check-ins and check-outs. 

* Enable managers to check in and check out of work for a worker.

* View workers who are currently checked in for work.

* Review and modify a worker's check-ins and check-outs. 

* View and create time blocks.

* View time entry validations for a worker.

* View period schedule for a worker.
info.title: timeTracking

tags.name: timeClockEvents
tags.description: These public APIs are designed to open up foundational Time Tracking functionality in REST. Use this API to give employees the ability to check in and check out of work and to review and modify their recent check-ins and check-outs. You can also use this API to enable managers to check in and check out of work for a worker, to view workers who are currently checked in for work, and to review and modify a worker's check-ins and check-outs.

tags.name: timeValidations
tags.description: Provides access to custom time entry validation information in Workday. These REST APIs enable employees to view validations related to the time they just entered, and managers to view validations related to the time they are reviewing.

tags.name: workerTimeBlocks
tags.description: Provides access to worker time block information in Workday.

tags.name: workers
tags.description: Retrieves staffing information about workers. This resource also provides the ability to create, update, delete, and archive check-ins and check-in topics.

tags.name: Prompt Values
tags.description: Retrieves instances that can be used as values for other endpoint parameters in this service.

get.description: Retrieves a worker time block with the specified ID. Secured by: Process: Time Block REST APIs Scope: Time Tracking

parameters.name: ID
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the resource.

200.description: Successful response. A successful response can return no matched data.

post.summary: Creates a Time Review Event or Time Review Events.
post.description: Creates a Time Review Event or Time Review Events for the specified worker. Specify these required fields in the request body: *date: the date that constructs the Time Review Event. The date is used to create Time Review Events for the Period or Week, depending on how that worker's Time Entry Template is configured. Additional optional field: *comment: Comment related to the BP that persists on each Time Review Event. Comments aren't allowed if disabled on the Enter Time BP To get more information about Custom Administrator configured Critical Time Validations, use the GET timeValidations API. This POST method is equivalent to Submit Time in Workday. Secured by: Manager: Time Tracking Manager Approval, Manager: Time Tracking Manager Edit and Approve, Submit Time (REST Service) Scope: Time Tracking, Time Tracking Hub

parameters.name: ID
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the resource.

Invalid request. (https://community.workday.com/rest/error-messages)
Error Code | Validation Message
--- | ---

A699 | Period Schedule does not exist for the \~worker\~, [worker], as of [date].
A734 | Time Entry Template does not exist for the \~worker\~, [worker], as of [date].
A789 | [date] is locked for time entry for [worker].
A947 | Specify a date to Submit Time.
A948 | No Time Blocks or Time Off to Submit exist in the period containing [date]. Enter Time in this period or specify a date that contains Time to Submit.
A949 | The period containing [date] caused Critical Time validation errors. To see details about the errors, use the Enter Time Calendar task.

get.summary: Retrieves a collection of time clock events for a worker for a date range.
get.description: Retrieves a collection of time clock events. You can filter by the time clock events by worker and date range. Secured by: Process: Time Clock Event REST API's Scope: Time Tracking

parameters.name: fromDate
parameters.description: The start date of the time event using the yyyy-mm-dd format.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects in a single response. The default is 20. The maximum is 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The zero-based index of the first object in a response collection. The default is 0. Use offset with the limit parameter to control paging of a response collection. Example: If limit is 5 and offset is 9, the response returns a collection of 5 objects starting with the 10th object.

parameters.name: toDate
parameters.description: The end date of the time event using the yyyy-mm-dd format.

parameters.name: worker
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the worker for the time block or clock event. You can specify multiple worker query parameters.

post.summary: Creates time clock events for specified workers.
post.description: Adds a time clock event for the specified worker. In the request body, these fields are required: * worker * eventType * dateTime * timeZone * Position can be required if worker has multiple positions. * One of timeEntryCode, project, or projectPlanTask. These fields are mutually exclusive. Specify 1 of these fields in the request body. For the timeEntryCode id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/timeEntryCodes, which returns the time entry codes that the given worker is eligible for on the given date. For a valid project id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projects, which you can filter by date and worker. For a valid projectPlanTask id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projectPlanTasks, which you can filter by date, worker, and project. Secured by: Process: Time Clock Event REST API's Scope: Time Tracking

get.description: Retrieves instances that can be used as values for other endpoint parameters in this service.

200.description: Successful response. A successful response can return no matched data.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The effective date to look up time values for a given worker.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects in a single response. The default and maximum is 1000.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The zero-based index of the first object in a response collection. The default is 0. Use offset with the limit parameter to control paging of a response collection. Example: If limit is 5 and offset is 9, the response returns a collection of 5 objects starting with the 10th object.

parameters.name: worker
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the worker to look up time values for.

get.summary: Retrieves a summary of reported hours for a worker over a period.
get.description: Retrieves a summary of reported hours for a worker over a period. The period contains the specified date or, if not specified, it contains today's date. Secured by: Process: Time Block REST APIs, Process: Time Clock Event REST API's Scope: Time Tracking

parameters.name: ID
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the resource.

parameters.name: subresourceID
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the subresource.

200.description: Successful response. A successful response can return no matched data.

get.summary: Retrieves a collection of time entry validations.
get.description: Retrieves a collection of time entry validations for the specified worker on the specified date. This method requires the date and worker query parameters. The validation messages returned by this method indicate that the time entries failed the critical or warning custom validations configured in the Maintain Time Entry Validations task. Secured by: Process: Time Block REST APIs Scope: Time Tracking

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The required date that determines the time entry validations. The method validates the time entries within week or time period of the specified date.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects in a single response. The default is 20. The maximum is 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The zero-based index of the first object in a response collection. The default is 0. Use offset with the limit parameter to control paging of a response collection. Example: If limit is 5 and offset is 9, the response returns a collection of 5 objects starting with the 10th object.

parameters.name: worker
parameters.description: The required Workday ID of the worker who entered the time entries.

200.description: Successful response. A successful response can return no matched data.

put.summary: Updates the time clock event for the specified ID.
put.description: Updates the time clock event for the specified ID. Replaces the existing time clock event with the specified data in the request body. The timeEntryCode, project, and projectPlanTask fields are mutually exclusive. You can only specify 1 of these fields in the request body. For the timeEntryCode id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/timeEntryCodes, which returns the time entry codes that the given worker is eligible for on the given date. For a valid project id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projects, which you can filter by date and worker. For a valid projectPlanTask id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projectPlanTasks, which you can filter by date, worker, and project. Secured by: Process: Time Clock Event REST API's Scope: Time Tracking

post.description: Creates a worker time block for the specified worker. Specify these required fields in the request body: * calendarDate and reportedQuantity - If the worker is hourly. * inTime, outTime, inTimeZone and outTimeZone - If the worker is in and out. * One of timeEntryCode, project, or projectPlanTask. These fields are mutually exclusive. Specify 1 of these fields in the request body. For the timeEntryCode id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/timeEntryCodes, which returns the time entry codes that the given worker is eligible for on the given date. For a valid project id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projects, which you can filter by date and worker. For a valid projectPlanTask id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projectPlanTasks, which you can filter by date, worker, and project. Secured by: Process: Time Block REST APIs Scope: Time Tracking

You can only specify 1 of these fields in the request body. For the timeEntryCode id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/timeEntryCodes, which returns the time entry codes that the given worker is eligible for on the given date. For a valid project id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projects, which you can filter by date and worker. For a valid projectPlanTask id, you can use a returned id from GET /values/timeTypes/projectPlanTasks, which you can filter by date, worker, and project. get.description: Retrieves instances that can be used as values for other endpoint parameters in this service.

200.description: Successful response. A successful response can return no matched data.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: The effective date to look up time values for a given worker.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects in a single response. The default and maximum is 1000.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The zero-based index of the first object in a response collection. The default is 0. Use offset with the limit parameter to control paging of a response collection. Example: If limit is 5 and offset is 9, the response returns a collection of 5 objects starting with the 10th object.

parameters.name: worker
parameters.description: The Workday ID of the worker to look up time values for.

get.summary: Retrieves time blocks for specified workers over a date range.
get.description: Retrieves time blocks for specified workers over a date range. This method does not return incomplete time blocks, time offs, and overtime request blocks. Secured by: Process: Time Block REST APIs Scope: Time Tracking

parameters.name: fromDate
parameters.description: The start date of the time block date range, using the yyyy-mm-dd format.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects in a single response. The default is 20. The maximum is 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: The zero-based index of the first object in a response collection. The default is 0. Use offset with the limit parameter to control paging of a response collection. Example: If limit is 5 and offset is 9, the response returns a collection of 5 objects starting with the 10th object.

parameters.name: phase
parameters.description:
The Workday ID of the project plan phase for the time block.
You can specify 1 or more project plan phase query parameters. 
You can use a returned id from the GET /planPhases endpoint in the Projects REST web service.

parameters.name: project
parameters.description:
The Workday ID of the project for the time block.
You can specify 1 or more project query parameters.
You can use a returned id from the GET /projects endpoint in the Projects REST web service.

parameters.name: projectPlanTask
parameters.description:
The Workday ID of the project plan task for the time block.
You can specify 1 or more project plan task query parameters.
You can use a returned id from the GET /planTasks endpoint in the Projects REST web service.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description:
The Workday ID of the approval status of the worker time block. Valid IDs are:

* Submitted: dd817fe688db4ac7bf84e3ef79f72948

* Unsubmitted (Not Submitted): ddf5968e6d4430ca4bce9a4cfaba337

* Approved: 0391102bd1b542538d996936c8fa2fa7

* Sent Back: 070b249867f747a19bca64f73eafc9b8

You can specify 1 or more status query parameters.

parameters.name: toDate
parameters.description: The end date of the time block date range, using the yyyy-mm-dd format.

parameters.name: worker
parameters.description:
The Workday ID of the worker for the time block. Specify workers that the user has permission to access.
You can specify 1 or more worker query parameters.
You can use returned ids from GET /workers.
